choices.C: A descending index is a type of function-based index.
choices.A: An index can be created as part of a CREATE TABLE statement.
choices.F: An INVINSIBLE INDEX is not maintained when Data Manipulation Language (DML) is performed on its underlying table.
choices.B: If a query filters on an indexed column, then it will always be used during execution of the query.
choices.D: A DROP INDEX statement always prevents updates to the table during the drop operation.
choices.E: A UNIQUE and non-unique index can be created on the same table column.

comments.content: C-FALSE: Function-based indexes: contain the precomputed value of a function/expression

discussion.content:
ABE IS CORRECT
A-TRUE
B-TRUE
C-FALSE
D-FALSE: The database automatically maintains indexes when you insert, update, and delete rows of
the associated table. If you drop an index, all applications continue to work. However,
access to previously indexed data might be slower.
E-TRUE
F-FALSE:Unlike unusable indexes, an invisible index is maintained during DML statements

comments.content: be created on the "same table column" ?

C is correct:

SQL> create table t1 (col1 number, col2 varchar2(10), col3 varchar2(10));

Table created.

Elapsed: 00:00:00.03
SQL> create unique index ix1 on t1(col1);

Index created.

Elapsed: 00:00:00.02
SQL> create index ix2 on t1(col1, col2);

Index created.

Elapsed: 00:00:00.01
SQL> create unique index ix3 on t1(col1, col2, col3);

Index created.

Elapsed: 00:00:00.02
SQL>

you can create both unique and non unique on the same set of columns not on one column 
option E is saying on the same table column making it wrong

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
A-
CREATE TABLE Books(
 ID NUMBER PRIMARY KEY USING INDEX (CREATE INDEX idx_custom_books_id ON books (ID)),
 Title VARCHAR2(100) NOT NULL,
 Author VARCHAR2(100) NOT NULL,
 PublishYear NUMBER NOT NULL
);

C- "Oracle Database treats descending indexes as if they were function-based indexes" 
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/sqlrf/CREATE-INDEX.html#GUID-1F89BBC0-825F-4215-AF71-7588E31D8BFE__GUID-92F4F0FB-499A-4ED7-8630-B219F8A50B90

E- "When you have multiple indexes on the same set of columns, only one of these indexes can be visible at a time, and any other indexes must be invisible."
"You can create multiple indexes on the same set of columns when at least one of the following index characteristics is different:
The indexes have different uniqueness properties.
You can create both a unique and a non-unique index on the same set of columns."
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/admin/managing-indexes.html#GUID-B4B30CF4-2B95-44D6-8596-EC2A378251EF

Correct is ACE, according the above evidences.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about indexes and their administration in an Oracle database? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DEF
Very good link, thanks dianiss1050. Yes correct answer are DEF.

False answer:
A - Protect the data dictionary. When parameter 07_DICTIONARY_ACCESSIBILITY is FALSE, people who has ANY TABLE privileges are restricted from accessing data dictionary-based tables. The default value of the parameter is FALSE and should not be changed.

B - Restrict remote database authentication. REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT specifies whether remote clients will be authenticated with the value of the OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX parameter. The default value is FALSE and should be like this. If set to TRUE, users created as “CREATE USER… IDENTIFIED EXTERNALLY” will be able to log in to the system.
C - The user granted by default for those packages is PUBLIC and NOT SYSTEM.

The answer is DEF 
https://dbtut.com/index.php/2020/01/09/principle-of-least-privilege-in-oracle-databases/

choices.A: setting the O7_DICTIONARY_ACCESSIBILITY parameter to true
choices.C: revoking execute privilege on UTL_SMTP, UTL_TCP, UTL_HTTP, and UTL_FILE from the SYSTEM user
choices.B: setting the REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT parameter to true
choices.F: revoking execute privilege on UTL_SMTP, UTL_TCP, UTL_HTTP, and UTL_FILE from the public user

questions.question_text:
The STORES table has a column START_DATE of data type DATE, containing the date the row was inserted.

You only want to display details of rows where START_DATE is within the last 25 months.

Which WHERE clause can be used?

discussion.content: but in E, there are mistake VA102, should be A102, this mistake was done on purpose? or its misstype?

Selected Answer: BE
The AND operator is evaluated earlier, it has higher priority than the OR operator. B and E examples differ only in parentheses, and those parentheses does not change the priority, because the priority of the AND is higher than the priority of the OR operator.

Selected Answer: BE
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/oracle/view/8434-exam-1z0-071-topic-1-question-274-discussion/

choices.D: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' OR menber_id IN ('A101', 'A102'));
choices.E: WHERE (borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND transaction_type - 'RM') OR member_id IN ('A101', VA102');
choices.B: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND transaction_type = 'RM' OR member_id IN ('A101', 'A102');
choices.A: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' AND member_id = 'A101' OR member_id = 'A102');
choices.C: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' AND (member_id = 'A101' OR member_id = 'A102'));
